The museum is indeed planning to incorporate some cutting-edge technology into the exhibit, including virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) components.

One of the highlights of the exhibit will be a VR experience that allows visitors to step into a reconstructed Late Cretaceous ecosystem, complete with roaming hadrosaurs, including Edmontosaurus. Using VR headsets, visitors will be able to explore the ancient landscape, getting up close and personal with these magnificent creatures in a way that would have been impossible in real life.

The AR component will be integrated into the exhibit through a mobile app, which visitors can download before or during their visit. Using the app, visitors will be able to point their devices at specific fossils or exhibits and unlock additional content, such as 3D models, videos, and interactive simulations. For example, visitors might use the app to:

1. **See a 3D model of an Edmontosaurus skeleton**: By pointing their device at a fossil display, visitors can see a 3D model of the skeleton, complete with interactive labels and information about the different bones.
2. **Watch a hadrosaur feeding simulation**: Visitors can use the app to trigger a simulation of a hadrosaur feeding on plants, complete with animations and sound effects.
3. **Explore a hadrosaur nest**: The app might allow visitors to explore a virtual hadrosaur nest, complete with eggs, nests, and other fossilized remains.

The museum is also planning to incorporate some innovative uses of projection mapping and interactive screens throughout the exhibit, which will help to create an immersive and engaging experience for visitors.

Overall, the museum is really pushing the boundaries of what's possible in a natural history exhibit, and I think visitors are going to be blown away by the combination of cutting-edge technology and fascinating fossil specimens.
